se254.money
Class Money

java.lang.Object
  extended by se254.money.Money

Changes

  • Valid amounts are now limited to the range -$999,999,999.9999 to $999,999,999.9999. Trying to create objects for amounts outside this range is undefined - it may work, or it may not. You don't need to test amounts outside this range.
  • The documentation now specifies what should happen when values for cents and hundredths outside the range [0..99] or [-99..99] are given (This was always supposed to be there - not sure what happened to the JavaDoc).
  • The behaviour of compareTo() when given null is now specified.
  • The behaviour of equals() when non-Money objects are given is now specifically stated to be undefined. (I can't imagine a situation where doing so could be anything other than a programming error, so checking the type and, for example, returning false, would just hide the existence of a fault.) 
public class Money
extends java.lang.Object

Represents money in dollars and cents to the nearest (that is, round up or down as appropriate) hundredth of a cent. Amounts can be negative. Money objects can only represent amounts between -$999,999,999.9999 and $999,999,999.9999. Behaviour when creating money objects for amounts outside this range is undefined. Money objects are immutable (once created, their state cannot be change).

Constructor Detail

Money

public Money()
An amount of zero.

Money

public Money(int dollars,
             int cents)
Create a money object representing the specified amount in dollars and cents. The most significant non-zero value can be negative to indicate a negative amount of money.

Parameters:
dollars - How many dollars. If non-zero, can be negative.
cents - How many cents. If dollars is non-zero, then must be in the range [0..99], otherwise if dollars is zero, can be in the range [-99..99].
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - with the message "Invalid: more than one negative value" if more than one of the arguments is negative.
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - with the message "Invalid: negative after non-zero" if one argument is negative but a more significant argument is postive.
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - with the message "Invalid value: out of range" if cents is out of the specified range.

Money

public Money(int dollars,
             int cents,
             int hundredths)
Create a money object representing the specified amount in dollars, cents, and hundredths of cents. The most significant non-zero value can be negative to indicate a negative amount of money.

Parameters:
dollars - How many dollars. If non-zero, can be negative.
cents - How many cents. If dollars is non-zero, then must be in the range [0..99], otherwise if dollars is zero, can be in the range [-99..99].
hundredths - How many hundredths of a cent. If at least one of dollars and cents is non-zero, then must be in the range [0..99], otherwise if both dollars and cents are zero, then can be in the range [-99..99].
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - with the message "Invalid: more than one negative value" if more than one of the arguments is negative.
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - with the message "Invalid: negative after non-zero" if one argument is negative but a more significant argument is positive.
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - with the message "Invalid value: out of range" if either cents or hundredths are out of the specified range.
Method Detail

add

public Money add(Money money)
Add the supplied money to this money and return a Money object that is the result of the addition of the two amounts.

Parameters:
money - What to add this Money object to. Must be non null.
Returns:
A money object that is the sum of this amount and the amount of what has been supplied.
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - with the message "Invalid: null argument" if money is null.

compareTo

public int compareTo(Money money)
Return -1 if the amount this Money object represents is less than the amount of the supplied object, 0 if they are equal, otherwise 1.

Parameters:
money - The supplied Money object
Returns:
Return -1 if the amount of this Money object is less than the amount of the supplied object, 0 if they are equal, otherwise 1.
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - with the message "Invalid: null argument" if money is null.

equals

public boolean equals(java.lang.Object obj)
Returns true if this object represents the same amount of money as the supplied object, otherwise false. If the supplied object is null, then the result is false. The behaviour is undefined if the supplied object is not a Money object.

Overrides:
equals in class java.lang.Object

multiply

public Money multiply(double factor)
Multiple the money amount by the specified factor, rounding to the nearest hundredths of a cent.

Parameters:
factor - How much to multiple the money amount by.
Returns:
A Money object corresponding to the result of the multiplication.

toString

public java.lang.String toString()
Return a string representation of this object. The string representation format is [-]$d+.dd[dd|d] - there can be an optional "-" (for negative amounts), followed by "$", followed by at least 1 digit (for dollars), followed by exactly 2 digits (for cents - trailing zeros are allowed), optionally followed by 1 or 2 digits (for hundredths - no trailing zeros allowed). Examples of correctly-formatted money are: "$14.99", "-$3.59", "$0.39", "$19.345". Examples of incorrectly-formatted money are: "14.99" (no $), "$-3.59" ($ in wrong place with respect to -), "$.39" (must be at least 1 digit in dollars, it should be 0 in this case), "$19.3450" (trailing zero in the hundredths not allowed).

Overrides:
toString in class java.lang.Object
